subject: History
title: Why Spices Mattered So Much
description: A micro-lesson that makes Why Spices Mattered So Much usable.

hook.text: In the 1400s, a handful of pepper was worth more than a day's wages. Spices were edible gold.

buildup.text: Before refrigeration, spices preserved meat, masked rot, and made bland grain diets bearable.

discovery.text: Cloves, nutmeg, and cinnamon grew only in tiny regions of Asia. Their scarcity made them precious.

twist.text: Arab and Venetian middlemen kept sources secret, marking up prices 1,000% along the trade chain.

climax.text: The desire to bypass these middlemen drove Portugal and Spain to risk everything on ocean voyages.

punchline.text: The Age of Exploration was powered by pepper.

quiz.question: Why did European nations seek direct sea routes to Asia?
options: To spread Christianity to new lands
To bypass middlemen and access cheap spices directly
To find new sources of gold and silver
